The results of the integrals in the previous exercise are \[ \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi }\sin nt \hspace{0.15cm} dt = 0 \] and \[ \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi }\cos nt \hspace{0.15cm} dt = 0 \] where \(n\) is an integer.

Note that any integration range \(\alpha\), \(\alpha + 2\pi\), would give these same (zero) answers.

These integrals enable enable us to calculate the constant term in the Fourier series given previously as \[ f(t) = \dfrac{a_0}{2} + \sum _{n=1}^{\infty} \left( a_n \cos nt + b_n \sin nt \right)\] Integrating both sides of the Fourier series from \( -\pi\) to \(\pi\) gives the left hand side as \[ \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi } f(t) \hspace{0.15cm} dt \] (whose value clearly depends on the function \(f(t)\)). Integrating the right-hand side term by term we get \[ \dfrac{1}{2} \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi } a_0 \hspace{0.15cm} dt + \sum _{n=1}^\infty \left\{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi a_n \cos nt \hspace{0.15cm} dt + \int _{-\pi}^\pi b_n \sin nt \hspace{0.15cm} dt \right\} = \dfrac{1}{2} \Big[ a_0 t \Big] _{-\pi}^\pi + \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left\{ 0 + 0 \right\} \] Thus we get \[ \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi } f(t) \hspace{0.15cm} dt = \dfrac{1}{2} (2 a_0 \pi ) \] or \[ a_0 = \dfrac{1}{\pi}\displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi } f(t) \hspace{0.15cm} dt \]

Key Point

The constant term in a trigonometric Fourier series for a function of period \(2\pi\) is \[ \dfrac{a_0}{2} = \dfrac{1}{2\pi} \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi } f(t) \hspace{0.15cm} dt \] which is the average value of \(f(t)\) over 1 period.

This result ties in with our earlier discussion on the significance of the constant term. Clearly a signal whose average value is zero will have no constant term in its Fourier series. The following square wave shown in the Figure below is an example.
